awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: IA: F: Latent and Graphical Models for Complex Dependent Data in Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a comprehensive research proposal on the statistical modeling and analysis for educational assessment. This research addresses issues concerning fundamental statistical problems that arise in the analysis of Big Data in education. The research focus is on modeling and inference for large-scale data with complex dependence and structures (such as high-dimensional response and process data). These data arise from the introduction of new methods of testing student knowledge that rely on scenarios presented to the students and on simulation-based environments where student responses to a simulated environment are tested. This research is collaborative between Columbia University  and the Educational Testing Service.

The topics studied include latent graphical modeling for high-dimensional item response data, modeling and segmentation of process data via dictionary models, estimation of item-attribute relationship, dimension reduction, theoretical analysis and computational methods for the proposed models. The analysis combines techniques and concepts from mathematics and probability and applies them to nonlinear statistical models and data analysis. The proposed model combines latent variable and graphical approaches for high-dimensional data; for modeling process data, recent advances in modeling and segmenting techniques for natural language processing will be investigated. In the theoretical development,  several algebraic concepts to formulate model identifiability and perform combinatorial analysis on high-dimensional discrete spaces will be studied. In addition, optimization algorithms will be developed using recent advances in numerical methods.

por.por_cntn:
This research project addresses issues concerning fundamental statistical problems that arise in the analysis of big data in education, for instance in the large-scale assessments such as the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) and the Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies (PIAAC). The research focus is on modeling and inference for large-scale data with complex dependence and structures (such as high-dimensional response and process data in problem-solving items). The specific topics include latent graphical modeling for high-dimensional item response data, modeling and segmentation of process data via dictionary models, estimation of item-attribute relationship, dimension reduction, theoretical analysis, and computational methods for the proposed models. This research helps achieve a deeper understanding of the complex data structures collected in technology-rich interactive tasks and provide guidelines to improve item quality with a focus on innovative item types such as scenario- and simulation-based environments for the assessment of students? knowledge and skills in the STEM fields.

The research started from developing methods in analyzing process data by sequence-based methods such as n-gram model borrowed from the natural language processing and text mining. By disassembling the long action sequences into mini-sequences, the key action features in success and unsuccess group in a specified digital problem-solving task could be identified. For instance, respondents in the success group showed patterns in following clear sub-goals and used digital tools when solving complex problems; while those in the unsuccess group showed hesitative behaviors by using "cancel" button more often and clicking on "help" function for further information. The sequence-based methods were extended to sequence distance measures to capture the consistency of individual?s problem-solving strategies and behavioral patterns. In this study, the distance between the optimal sequences that were defined by content expert and item developers and each observed individual sequence was computed. Two indicators of sequence similarity and sequence efficiency were defined, which interprets how similar the individual sequence is compared with optimal reference sequence and what percentage of the redundant actions were adopted when solving the digital tasks. The results showed that most respondents keep consistent behaviors when solving digital tasks. The respondents with high-level problem-solving skills showed more similar sequences compared with the reference ones than those with low-level skills. The respondents with extremely low- or high-level skills showed more consistent distance compared with the reference sequences.

The elapsed time between each action was also leveraged in the study. A graph-based clustering analysis was conducted based on action features and time information to illustrate the different behavioral patterns even though with the same action sequences. It gave a deeper insight on how respondents paused, thought and hesitated during the cognitive process. The result also showed the respondents who consistently employed long action sequences within short time period obtained the highest score in problem-solving tasks.

All the results throughout this project, with a collaboration with Columbia University, were highlighted in a good variety of publications, research report, training materials and conference presentations. Till the end of this project, the production has included a total of 13 journal papers (incl. 10 papers fully published, and 3 papers are under review), 1 book, 3 book chapters, 3 research reports, 28 invited talks, and 42 conference presentations. These studies essentially help researchers get better view on new data source in large-scale assessments and set the research team intellectual leadership in this new field.

With the increasing use of computer-based testing, a variety of high-dimensional and complex structured data have been collected. The results of this research provide a deeper understanding of the complex data structures collected in technology-rich interactive tasks. It shed light on items in learning and assessment environments that are delivered online both in client server constellations and in standalone applications. The analysis of process data not only provides large amount of information for test takers/students? behaviors, thus facilitating improvement in teachers? instructions, but also lays a solid foundation in understanding the reasons why students show such behaviors in different situation. The studies in this direction holds promise to make significant contributions to adaptive learning and testing which will be in critical needs in the 21st century. Furthermore, the item development and innovative designs will also benefit from these studies to adapt to the new demands in education.
